revision.text:
[[Gian Francesco Malipiero]]'s '''Terza Sinfonia, ''delle Campane''''' is the third of his eleven numbered [[symphony|symphonies]] and it was completed in February 1945, two months before the end of the [[Second World War]] in Italy with the fall of the [[Italian Social Republic]]. It was premiered on November 4 in [[Florence]], with [[Igor Markevitch]] conducting.
The composition is inspired by the pealing of the [[St Mark's Campanile]]'s bells in [[Venice]], where Malipiero lived. The mournful finale reflects the night in September 1943 when the bells proclaimed the foundation of the Social Republic. In the composer's words, ''[the symphony] is connected to a terrible date, 18 September 1943. At dusk of that unforgettable day the bells of San Marco rang, but they couldn't deceive those who knew their true voice. They didn't ring for peace, but to announce new torments, more anguish''.<ref>[http://www.flaminioonline.it/Guide/Malipiero-Sinfonia3.html Program notes] from a 1969 [[Accademia Nazionale di Santa Cecilia]] concert, quoted in the Flaminio Virtual Orchestra's website</ref>
The symphony lasts c. 24 minutes, and it consists of four movements:
#''Allegro moderato'' #''Andante molto moderato'' #''Vivace'' #''Lento''
==Recordings== * [[Moscow Symphony Orchestra|Moscow Symphony]] – [[Antonio de Almeida (conductor)|Antonio de Almeida]]. [[Marco Polo Records|Marco Polo]], 1993 (later reissued by [[Naxos Records|Naxos]])
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Gian Francesco Malipiero}} {{classical-music-stub}}
[[Category:Compositions by Gian Francesco Malipiero]] [[Category:20th-century symphonies|Malipiero]] [[Category:1945 compositions]]

{{short description|fictional region of Catalonia}} {{POV|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} [[File:Tabarnia.jpg|right|thumb|Proposed extent of Tabarnia.]] [[File:Flag of Tabarnia.SVG|right|thumb|Proposed flag of Tabarnia.]] [[File:Tabarnia amb vot independentista-unionista.png|right|thumb|Theoretical extent of Tabarnia (left), compared to the results of the [[Catalan regional election, 2017|2017 Catalan regional election]]. Red-colored regions supported [[Spanish unionism|unionist]] parties; blue-colored regions supported separatist parties. Note – votes for Podemos, which supports a referendum yet opposes independence are not considered as part of either camp.]]
'''Tabarnia''' ({{IPA-ca|təβəɾˈni.ə}}; {{IPA-es|taˈβaɾnja|lang}}) is a fictional region within [[Catalonia]],<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Burgen | first1 = Stephen | title = Fictional Catalan region of Tabarnia appoints first president | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/16/fictional-region-tabarnia-aiming-leave-catalonia-appoints-president | work = The Guardian | date = 16 January 2018 }}</ref> a [[satirical]] [[parody]] of the [[Catalan independence movement]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 'Tabarnia', el reverso satírico del independentismo catalán | publisher = RTVE.es | language = Spanish | url = http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20171227/tabarnia-reverso-satirico-del-independentismo-catalan/1651625.shtml | date = 27 December 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Tabarnia, región ficticia con ansias de secesión de la Cataluña independentista | publisher = France 24 | language = Spanish | url = http://www.france24.com/es/20171226-tabarnia-region-ficticia-con-ansias-de-secesion-de-la-cataluna-independentista | date = 27 December 2017 }}</ref><ref name="TheLocal">{{cite web | title = Tabarnia – the 'region' that wants to leave Catalonia | publisher = The Local | url = https://www.thelocal.es/20171227/tabarnia-region-independence-catalonia-spain | date = 27 December 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = The Catalan independence parody with its own president | publisher = BBC | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-42777496 | date = 24 January 2018 }}</ref> and a movement against the independence of Catalonia from Spain<ref>{{cite news | title = Fictional Tabarnia is officially a movement | url = http://www.euronews.com/2018/01/17/fictional-tabarnia-is-officially-a-movement | work = [[Euronews]] | date = 17 January 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Encontramos a los creadores de Tabarnia: "Si los 'indepes' siguen con la matraca, tendremos referéndum tabarnés"  | work = El Mundo | location = Spain | language = Spanish | url = http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2017/12/31/5a47d93e468aeb56238b4587.html | date = 31 December 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last1 = Blanchar | first1 = Clara | title = La plataforma por Tabarnia exhibe músculo y se manifiesta en Barcelona | url = https://elpais.com/ccaa/2018/03/04/catalunya/1520162880_273146.html | work = [[El País]] | date = 4 March 2018 | language = es }}</ref> advocating a referendum<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2017/12/31/5a47d93e468aeb56238b4587.html | title = We find the creators of Tabarnia. If the independists continue with this "story" we will have a Tabarnian referendum | language = Spanish | work = [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] | date = 31 December 2017 | accessdate = 16 January 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2018/01/16/5a5dda91e5fdeae7238b45e9.html | title = The promoters of Tabarnia are willing to be a threat to separatism | language = Spanish | work = [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] | date = 16 January 2017 | accessdate = 16 January 2018 }}</ref> to create a new [[Autonomous communities of Spain|Spanish autonomous community]] out of coastal urban parts of Catalonia that would decide to remain part of Spain in case of a hypothetical Catalan independence. It would encompass the current [[Catalonia|Catalan]] ''[[comarques]]'' of [[Tarragonès|Tarragonés]], [[Baix Camp]], [[Baix Penedès]], [[Alt Penedès]], [[Garraf]], [[Baix Llobregat]], [[Barcelonès]], [[Vallès Oriental]], [[Vallès Occidental]] and [[Maresme]].
Proponents believe the area somewhat corresponds to the historic [[County of Barcelona]], although its extent is considerably different.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/12/27/latest-satirical-campaign-for-barcelona-secession-hit.html | title = The Latest: Satirical campaign for Barcelona secession a hit | date = 27 December 2017 | publisher = Fox News Channel | access-date = 16 January 2018 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180116193352/http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/12/27/latest-satirical-campaign-for-barcelona-secession-hit.html | archive-date = 16 January 2018 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref> This proposal, from a platform created in 2011, was shown to map the electoral results of the Catalan regional election of 21 December 2017, which provoked renewed interest. The word 'Tabarnia' went viral on 26 December 2017, reaching worldwide top-trending status with over 648,000 mentions. The first major demonstration organized by the Tabarnia movement took place in Barcelona on 4 March 2018, with 15,000 participants according to the Guarda Urbana and 200,000 according to organizers.<ref>https://elpais.com/ccaa/2018/03/04/catalunya/1520162880_273146.html</ref>
The reaction from Catalan pro-secession movements has been very critical,<ref name=movement>{{cite news | last1 = Baquero | first1 = David Alandete, Camilo S. | title = Tabarnia: the hoax independence movement trending now in Spain | url = https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/12/27/inenglish/1514368061_809906.html | work = [[El País]] | date = 27 December 2017 }}</ref> with some separatists using the same arguments against the proposal to create Tabarnia as those used by those who oppose the creation of an independent Catalan Republic.<ref>{{cite news | title = Por qué Tabarnia está sacando de quicio a los independentistas | url = https://www.elindependiente.com/politica/2017/12/27/por-que-tabarnia-sacando-quicio-independentistas/ | accessdate = 5 March 2018 | work = El Independiente | date = 27 December 2017 | language = es-ES }}</ref> [[Jaume Vives]], the self-claimed spokesman for the Tabarnia proposal,<ref name=":3">{{Cite news | url = https://www.elsaltodiario.com/independencia-de-catalunya/tabarnia-capital-forocoches | title = Tabarnia capital forocoches | last = Ferrero | first = Àngel | date = 4 March 2018 | work = El Salto | access-date = 5 April 2018 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180406041445/https://www.elsaltodiario.com/independencia-de-catalunya/tabarnia-capital-forocoches | archive-date = 6 April 2018 | dead-url = no | language = Spanish | df = }}</ref> stated: "It is starting to achieve its objective, that the (Catalan) independentists start debunking their own arguments."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.elperiodico.com/es/politica/20171226/que-es-tabarnia-propuesta-secesion-barcelona-tarragona-resto-cataluna-6517873 | title = ¿Qué es Tabarnia? | language = Spanish | publisher = [[El Periódico de Catalunya]] | date = 26 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref>
Currently it is not known who is in charge of the so-called Tabarnia movement and who invented the original concept of Tabarnia. [[Jaume Vives]] and [[Albert Boadella]] have self-proclaimed to be the spokesman and president of Tabarnia.<ref name=":3" /> Miquel Martinez presents itself as the representative of Platform for Tabarnia,<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/Tabarnia-inicia-movilizacion-ofrenda-soberanismo_0_746475524.html | title = La Plataforma por Tabarnia sale a la calle en Barcelona | work = eldiario.es | access-date = 13 May 2018 | language = es | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180514065025/https://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/Tabarnia-inicia-movilizacion-ofrenda-soberanismo_0_746475524.html | archive-date = 14 May 2018 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref> but in the association registry of Catalonia only exists the "Associació Somos Tabarnia" (Association We are Tabarnia).<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://justicia.gencat.cat/ca/serveis/guia_d_entitats/entitats_xml/index.html | title = Dades Entitats Jurídiques en XML | website = Departament de Justícia | language = ca-ES | access-date = 13 May 2018 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171105161520/http://justicia.gencat.cat/ca/serveis/guia_d_entitats/entitats_xml/index.html | archive-date = 5 November 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref> At a Spain level two other platforms exist: "Coordinadora por Tabarnia" and "Asamblea Nacional de Tabarnia".<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.interior.gob.es/web/servicios-al-ciudadano/asociaciones | title = Asociaciones | website = Ministerio de Interior de España | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180106195542/http://www.interior.gob.es/web/servicios-al-ciudadano/asociaciones | archive-date = 6 January 2018 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref>
== Movement == [[File:Tabarnia protest.jpg|thumb|Tabarnia's movement protest on 4 March 2018 against Catalan independence from Spain]] [[File:Martinez-Tabarnia-Llegaremos-independentismo-quiera EDIIMA20180304 0164 4.jpg|thumb|Floral offering to [[Rafael Casanova]] during the protest]] Proponents of Tabarnia wish to distance themselves from the Catalan separatist movement and reclaim the right of a number of territories near the area of Barcelona and Tarragona to constitute themselves as an autonomous community within Spain. In the [[Catalan regional election, 2015|2015]] and [[Catalan regional election, 2017|2017]] Catalan regional elections, parties opposed to secession (mainly [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Citizens]], [[Socialists' Party of Catalonia|PSC]] and [[People's Party of Catalonia|PP]]) received a [[Majority#Majority vote|majority]] of votes and seats in Tabarnia as a whole and in a small number of coastal ''comarques'' (Tarragonès, Baix Penedès and Baix Llobregat) including the city of Tarragona. They received a [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] of votes in the comarca of [[Barcelonès]], yet not in the city of [[Barcelona]] itself. They allude to a series of fiscal arguments similar to those of Catalan separatism in regards to Spain. The term "Tabarnia" is a [[neologism]] based on the names of [[Province of Tarragona|Tarragona]] and [[Province of Barcelona|Barcelona]], the two Catalan provinces where support for separatism is lower,<ref>{{cite web | title = Tabarnia, por una Barcelona fuera de Cataluña | url = http://www.abc.es/espana/abci-tabarnia-barcelona-fuera-cataluna-201712262016_noticia.html | language = Spanish | work = [[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] | date = 26 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref> although in last Catalan election, Tarragona province showed more support for separatism than [[Spanish unionism|unionism]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Resultados de las elecciones catalanas en la provincia de Tarragona: el constitucionalismo gana un escaño | url = http://www.abc.es/elecciones/catalanas/abci-resultados-elecciones-catalanas-provincia-tarragona-ganan-independentistas-201712212200_noticia.html | work = [[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] | language = es-ES }}</ref>
The movement uses as a legal basis the [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Clarity Act]], according to which regions opposed to [[Quebec sovereignty movement|Quebecois separatism]] are to remain within Canada in case of a secession, as well as Articles 143 and 144 of the [[Spanish constitution]], which allows the formation of autonomous communities.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tabarnia, el golpe de realidad del independentismo | url = http://www.cope.es/noticias/elecciones-catalanas/tabarnia-golpe-realidad-del-independentismo_165916 | language = Spanish | publisher = [[Cadena COPE]] | date = 27 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref>
An ongoing online petition is taking place at [[Change.org]] in order to be sent to the Spanish [[Congress of Deputies]] to consider the creation of this new autonomous region.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.elcatalan.es/la-campana-apoyo-tabarnia-change-org-ronda-las-100-000-firmas/ | title = 100.000 signatures to request consideration of Autonomous Region of Tabarnia in Spanish Congress. | language = Spanish | publisher = [[elcatalan.es]] | date = 7 February 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref> It has received 281 000 signatures to date.<ref name=parody>{{cite news | title = Tabarnia: The parody with its own president | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-42777496 | work = ''BBC News'' | date = 24 January 2018 }}</ref><ref name="protest" />
On 4 March 2018 a protest mocking the Catalan independence bid was organized by the Tabarnia movement. 15 000 demonstrators according to the [[Guàrdia Urbana de Barcelona|urban guard]] and 200 000 according to the organizers gathered with Spanish, Tabarnian and Catalan flags and waived slogans for Tabarnia mimicking those of the Catalan independence movement. The protest started with a floral offering at the statue of [[Rafael Casanova]], Considered by the independentists a patriot of their cause, but that according to one of his descendants present at the protest was actually a Spanish patriot.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tabarnia se manifiesta por primera vez en Barcelona para mostrar su hartazgo del independentismo | url = http://www.lasexta.com/noticias/nacional/tabarnia-inicia-movilizacion-barcelona-ofrenda-floral-monumento-rafael-casanova_201803045a9be06e0cf2daf6913351dd.html | accessdate = 4 March 2018 | work = [[laSexta]] | date = 4 March 2018 | language = es }}</ref> According to one of the organizers, the goal of the protest was to show the absurdity of the arguments for independence. He told the media that "we want to be the mirror of what the independence movement is all about". The protest was also criticized by some separatists which claim that Tabarnia trivializes their movement, which according to them is based on a distinct cultural identity and a long history of tension with Madrid.<ref name="protest">{{cite news | last1 = Martin | first1 = Nik | title = Protesters mock Catalan independence bid with secession call of their own | url = http://www.dw.com/en/protesters-mock-catalan-independence-bid-with-secession-call-of-their-own/a-42819202 | accessdate = 4 March 2018 | publisher = [[Deutsche Welle]] | date = 4 March 2018 }}</ref> The protest ended at [[Plaça Sant Jaume|Saint James's Square]], directly across from the [[Palau de la Generalitat de Catalunya]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Tabarnia vive hoy su primera manifestación | url = http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20180304/441250046559/tabarnia-manifestacion-3-marzo.html | accessdate = 4 March 2018 | work = [[La Vanguardia]] | date = 4 March 2018 | language = es }}</ref>
The protest on 4 March received support from some civic and political associations, including the pro Spanish union platform [[Societat Civil Catalana]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite news | url = http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20180215/44801100685/sociedad-civil-y-plataforma-tabarnia-unidos-en-manifestacion-del-dia-25.html | title = Societat Civil Catalana secunda a Tabarnia en la manifestación del 25 de febrero | work = La Vanguardia | access-date = 30 March 2018 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180330233949/http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20180215/44801100685/sociedad-civil-y-plataforma-tabarnia-unidos-en-manifestacion-del-dia-25.html | archive-date = 30 March 2018 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref> and far-right political parties like [[Platform for Catalonia|PxC]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite web | url = https://www.plataforma.cat/noticies/3990/tabarnia-ja-es-aqui-pxc-convidada-a-la-seva-primera-manifestacio.html | title = PxC – Tabàrnia ja és aquí! PxC convidada a la seva primera manifestació | website = plataforma.cat | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180331224334/https://www.plataforma.cat/noticies/3990/tabarnia-ja-es-aqui-pxc-convidada-a-la-seva-primera-manifestacio.html | archive-date = 1 April 2018 | dead-url = | access-date = 31 March 2018 }}</ref> and [[Vox (Spanish political party)|Vox]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Vox leaders supporting Tabarnia demonstration | publisher = VOX Noticias | url = https://twitter.com/voxnoticias_es/status/970274531725201408 }}{{Primary source inline|date=August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web | url = http://www.eltriangle.eu/es/notices/2018/01/-que-influencers-ha-retratado-el-fenomeno-tabarnia-9930.php | title = ¿Qué 'influencers' ha retratado el fenómeno Tabarnia? | date = 19 January 2018 | website = | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180331224647/http://www.eltriangle.eu/es/notices/2018/01/-que-influencers-ha-retratado-el-fenomeno-tabarnia-9930.php | archive-date = 1 April 2018 | dead-url = | access-date = 1 April 2018 }}</ref>
An online petition was begun on [[Change.org]] to have the name of the {{lang|ca|Plaça Països Catalans}} (Catalan Countries Square) changed to "{{lang|es|Plaza Tabarnia}}".<ref>{{cite news | last1 = García | first1 = Luis B. | title = Tabarnia recoge firmas para cambiar el nombre de la plaza Països Catalans por plaza Tabarnia | url = http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20180214/44779578180/tabarnia-firmas-nombre-plaza-paisos-catalans.html | accessdate = 25 April 2018 | work = La Vanguardia | date = n.d. | language = ca }}</ref>
== Political claims == Tabarnians claim vote representation in Catalonia to be unfair across the four different provinces Lleida, Girona, Tarragona and Barcelona, resulting in unfair economic investment. Under the current electoral law, in the province of Barcelona 48,521 votes are needed to elect one representative in the Catalan Parlament for the 20,915 votes needed in Lleida, resulting in a 2.3 ratio. Tarragona requires 31,317 votes and Girona 30,048. Catalan separatists argue the current electoral law ensures political representation for areas with a lower population density while tabarnians argue the law has not been revised because historically Lleida and Girona have always had a majority of voters in favor of the separatist political parties that have kept them in government.<ref>{{cite web | title = Vote representation in Catalonia | url = http://www.bcnisnotcat.es/2015/11/siel-voto-de-todos-los-catalanes.html | language = Spanish | publisher = Bcnisnotcat.es | date = 27 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref>
The same way Catalan separatist have used an interpretation of economic data to argue they have an unfavourable finance balance towards the rest of Spain, Tabarnians argue Tarragona and Barcelona underrepresentation in the Catalan Parlament has resulted in unfavourable finance balance towards their region, also backed by similar interpretation of economic data.<ref>{{cite web | title = Economic investment disparity in Barcelona | url = http://www.bcnisnotcat.es/2017/08/cataluna-roba-barcelona-164-millones-de.html | language = Spanish | publisher = Bcnisnotcat.es | date = 27 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref>
The Tabarnia Movement is still in its early days and is too soon to know how their political claims will unfold. Some Tabarnians simply believe this movement to be a satirical response that mirrors separatist with their own logic. Some Tabarnians demand that, in case a hypothetycal referendum for Catalonia independence was held, the seven different veguerias ([[Vegueria]]) be decided separately, so "Tarragona" and "Àmbit metropolità" are not declared independent against their democratic will. Some Tabarnians have grown so tired of the Catalan separatist movement, that they seem committed to celebrating a referendum in October 2018 to split from Catalonia as a Spanish autonomous region whether the previous referendum takes place or not. Some Tabarnians want to be declared a new autonomous region, which they argue is legally plausible under the present [[Spanish Constitution of 1978]].{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
== Demonym == On 27 December 2017, following public enquiry by Spanish citizens, the [[Real Academia Española]] (Royal Academy of Spanish Language) informed through their Twitter account that the most appropriate demonym for Tabarnia would be "Tabarnés" among other possible options such as "tabarniense", "tabarniano", or "tabinososano".<ref>{{cite web | url = https://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/12/28/actualidad/1514482134_672304.html | title = RAE demonym | language = Spanish | work = [[El País]] | date = 27 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref>
== Hypothetical territory and historical revisionism == [[File:Àmbits de Catalunya 1995.svg|thumb|Catalan regional plan 1995, used as the basis for different veguerias projects. {{unbulleted list | {{legend2|#f37373|Àmbit metropolità}} | {{legend2|#73f3f3|Alt Pirineu i Aran}} | {{legend2|#73f373|Tarragona}} | {{legend2|#7373f3|Comarques Centrals}} | {{legend2|#f3f373|Comarques Gironines}} | {{legend2|#f373f3|Ponent}} | {{legend2|#b3b373|Terres de l'Ebre}} }}]]
Tabarnia is a fictional territorial proposal that does not correspond to any present political or administrative unit.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news | last1 = Minder | first1 = Raphael | title = Fake Country Carved From Catalonia Means to Mock Separatism | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/27/world/europe/catalonia-spain-tabarnia-puigdemont-rajoy.html | work = The New York Times | year = 2018 }}</ref> The tabarnian movement mirrors the alleged [[historical revisionism]] by Catalan separatists,<ref>{{cite news | title = Los siete reinos de Cataluña, la última teoría histórica de los independentistas . Noticias de Cataluña | url = https://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2014-08-10/los-7-reinos-de-cataluna-la-ultima-teoria-de-los-independentistas_174281/ | work = [[El Confidencial]] | date = 10 August 2014 | language = es }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = El mito de los "países catalanes": el invento de un valenciano en 1962 | url = http://www.abc.es/espana/comunidad-valenciana/abci-mito-paises-catalanes-invento-valenciano-1962-201605021732_noticia.html | work = [[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] | date = 12 May 2016 | language = es-ES }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Machado el 'franquista' y los 10 delirios históricos del separatismo catalán | url = http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2017/08/22/599874a522601d8e3b8b4625.html | work = [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] | date = 22 August 2017 | language = es }}</ref> and finds a precedent of territorial political and administrative unit at a certain point in history that justifies their existence: According to their own publication, the County of Barcelona, during the Middle Ages, had a similar territory to the one proposed by Tabarnians, today.<ref>{{cite web | title = bcnisnotcat Tabarnia, territory | url = http://www.bcnisnotcat.es/2015/09/territorio.html | language = Spanish | publisher = bcnisnotcat.com | date = 27 December 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref> Most sources consider Tabarnia to be just a fictional region.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Madrid | first1 = Graham Keeley | title = Fictitious region of Tabarnia seeks independence from Catalonia | url = https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/fictitious-region-of-tabarnia-seeks-independence-from-catalonia-03bxt07vm | work = The Times | date = 6 January 2018 }}</ref><ref name=parody />
The present day official distribution of Catalonia's counties grouped in "Veguerias" ([[Vegueria]]), show a territorial distribution where "Tarragona" and "Àmbit metropolità" match the territory proposed for Tabarnia.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2010/07/27/barcelona/1280220047.html | title = Catalan Parlament approves new territorial distribution. | accessdate = 28 December 2017 | work = El Mundo | date = 22 December 2017 | language = Spanish }}</ref>
== Controversy == The movements founders, Catalan politicians such as [[Inés Arrimadas]] and numerous commentators have argued that the rise of this movement creates tension among the Catalan separatist movement because it serves as a mirror of their argumental contradiction.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tabarnia: The new Catalan secessionist movement boosted by Twitter | url = http://www.euronews.com/2017/12/27/tabarnia-the-new-catalan-secessionist-movement-boosted-by-twitter | publisher = [[Euronews]] | date = 27 December 2017 }}</ref> By using their same arguments for independence,<ref name="TheLocal" /> it forces Catalan separatists to contradict themselves by using "[[Spanish unionism|unionist]]" counter-arguments in order to discredit the Tabarnia movement.<ref name=movement /><ref>{{cite news | title = Por qué Tabarnia está sacando de quicio a los independentistas | url = https://www.elindependiente.com/politica/2017/12/27/por-que-tabarnia-sacando-quicio-independentistas/ | work = El Independiente | date = 27 December 2017 | language = es-ES }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D8z6M9283ks | title = Margallo and Joan Tardà during a congress session of foreign affairs. | language = Spanish | publisher = [[Youtube video]] | date = 7 February 2017 | accessdate = 27 December 2017 }}</ref>
By proposing the hypothetical separation of Tabarnia from Catalonia, the founders of the Tabarnia project want for the separatist politicians to realize that a large proportion of Catalans consider themselves Spanish and do no not want to leave Spain and that a declaration of independence could trigger similar movements within the territory, to the point of absurdity. According to Manuel Muñiz, the dean of the school of international relations at IE University in Madrid, it sparked a debate over "who is to vote and when" in a democracy and he questioned whether regions should be the ones entitled to decide on their independence or if cities would also qualify? Or should it be neighborhoods within cities?<ref name=NYT />
According to Salvador Garcia Ruiz, the chief executive of [[Ara (newspaper)|''Ara'']], a Catalan pro-independence newspaper, Tabarnia is nothing more than a sour response to the results of the [[Catalan regional election, 2017]] in which the independentists did not lose their majority over the parliament. He labeled Tabarnia as [[Peter Pan]]'s "Neverland" for the unionists. Podemos' leader [[Pablo Iglesias Turrión|Pablo Iglesias]] was also critical with the movement because he claimed it was fueling an unhelpful "war of flags" but the spokesman for Tabarnia claims that the goal was never to break up Catalonia, but rather ending Catalan secessionism and all its disruptive consequences.<ref name=NYT />
== See also == * [[Constitutional status of Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles]] * [[Partition of Quebec]] * [[West Virginia in the American Civil War]] * Other [[Autonomous communities of Spain|Autonomous Communities]] that have been created in Spain using the above-mentioned articles of the [[Spanish Constitution of 1978|Spanish Constitution]] ** [[Community of Madrid]] ** [[La Rioja (Spain)|Community of La Rioja]] ** The [[Albacete (Cortes of Castilla-La Mancha constituency)|Province of Albacete]] was originally part of the [[Region of Murcia|Community of Murcia]] (before it had an autonomous government) but was then reassigned to [[Castilla-La Mancha|Castilla La Mancha]] when regions were given autonomous governments ** [[Ceuta]] and [[Melilla]] were originally part of the [[Cadiz province]] and [[Province of Malaga|Malaga province]] respectively within the Autonomous Community of [[Andalusia]], after which they were granted a new status as autonomous cities, separating both from their province and from Andalusia. * [[Catalan Countries]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Jean_Auguste_Dominique_Ingres,_Apotheosis_of_Homer,_1827.jpg | title=The Apotheosis of Homer | artist=[[Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres|Ingres]] | year=1827 | medium=oil on canvas | height_metric=386 | width_metric=512 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=Louvre | city=Paris }} '''''The Apotheosis of Homer''''' is a grand 1827 painting by [[Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres]], now exhibited at the [[Louvre]] as INV 5417. The symmetrical composition depicts [[Homer]] being crowned by a winged figure personifying Victory or the Universe. Forty-four additional figures pay homage to the poet in a kind of classical confession of faith. ==History== A state commission to decorate a ceiling of the musée [[Charles X of France|Charles X]] at the Louvre (now the ancient Egyptian galleries), it formed part of a renovation project commissioned by Charles X to have himself remembered in the grand tradition of [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]] building works at the Louvre. A condition of the commission was that it was to be completed within a year's time.Condon et al. 1983, p. 110. Upon receiving the commission, Ingres conceived the idea for his painting quickly—it was a source of pride to him that he had required only an hour to establish the broad outlines of his composition. The subsequent care he took in developing his idea is evident in more than 100 drawings and numerous painted sketches for it that survive, in which he can be seen making the composition and the details more and more precise. Ingres's level of research can be seen in the painting's portrait of [[Nicolas Poussin]], which is directly copied from Poussin's [[:File:Nicolas Poussin 078.jpg|1650 self-portrait]] now in the Louvre. The composition is a symmetrical grouping centred in a [[Neoclassicism|classical]] way in front of an [[ancient Greek]] temple. The painting's catalogue entry at the time of its first exhibition describes it as "Homer receiving homage from all the great men of [[ancient Greece|Greece]], [[ancient Rome|Rome]] and modern times. The Universe crowns him, [[Herodotus]] burns [[frankincense|incense]].Behind Homer, to the left, with his head covered to make a sacrifice, as was customary in classical religious practice, as with the [[Via Labicana Augustus]]. The [[Iliad]] and [[Odyssey]] sit at his feet." [[File:Study for Phidias in 'The Apotheosis of Homer' by Ingres, San Diego Museum of Art.JPG|thumb|Study for Phidias in ''The Apotheosis of Homer'', oil on canvas, 1827, [[San Diego Museum of Art]]]] The final painting's colours are very fresh and clear, giving the impression of [[fresco]]. Ingres wished to compete with [[Raphael]] through this painting (it is strongly inspired by the Italian artist's ''[[The Parnassus|Parnassus]]'') and Raphael is to be seen top left (in black and white Renaissance dress), being led by [[Apelles]] (in a blue cloak). Other figures shown include [[Dante]] who is shown being led by [[Virgil]] as in the former's ''[[Divine Comedy]]'' (extreme left, behind Poussin) and [[Molière]] (right, by the feet of the personification of the ''Odyssey''). The art historian [[Robert Rosenblum]] said ''The Apotheosis of Homer'' represents "Ingres' most doctrinaire statement of his belief in a hierarchy of timeless values that are based on classical precedent."Rosenblum 1990, p. 100. It is highly successful in its genre, though leaves an impression of coldness, an impression which was reinforced at the time of its production by the exhibition of [[Eugène Delacroix|Delacroix]]'s ''[[Death of Sardanapalus|The Death of Sardanapalus]]'' at the same year's [[Paris Salon]]. Ingres had been considered revolutionary early in his career, but this contrast now faced off a [[Romanticism|Romantic]] renewal under Delacroix against the purest classical tradition as shown by Ingres. ''The Apotheosis of Homer'' was taken down from its initial site in 1855 and replaced later that year with a copy by Paul and Raymond Balze (in collaboration with Michel Dumas).[http://cartelen.louvre.fr/cartelen/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=15321 The Balzes' copy] ==Figures shown== Surrounding Homer are poets, artists, and philosophers both ancient and modern—the modern personages are mostly confined to the lower register of the composition, although Ingres deemed [[Raphael]] and [[Michelangelo]] worthy of elevation to stand alongside the ancients. The figures are:Radius 1968, p. 103. {|align=center |[[File:Apoteosi di Omero personaggi.jpg|border|570px]] ||
#[[Horacio]] #[[Peisistratos]] #[[Lycurgus of Athens|Lycurgus]] #[[Virgil]] #[[Rafael Sanzio|Rafael]] #[[Sappho]] #[[Alcibiades]] #[[Apelles]] #[[Euripides]] #[[Menandro]] #[[Demosthenes]] #[[Sophocles]] #[[Aeschylus]] #[[Herodotus]] #[[Orpheus]] #[[Linus (mythology)|Linus]] #[[Homer]] #[[Musaeus of Athens]] #Victory or the Universe #[[Pindar]] #[[Hesiod]] #[[Plato]] #[[Socrates]] #[[Pericles]] #[[Pheidias]] #[[Michelangelo]] #[[Aristotle]] #[[Aristarchus of Samothrace]] #[[Alexander the Great]] #[[Dante]] #''[[Iliad]]'' personification #''[[Odyssey]]'' personification #[[Aesop]] #[[William Shakespeare]] #[[Jean de la Fontaine]] #[[Torquato Tasso]] #[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] #[[Nicolas Poussin]] #[[Pierre Corneille]] #[[Jean Racine]] #[[Molière]] #[[Nicolas Boileau]] #[[Longino]] #[[François Fénelon]] #[[Christoph Willibald Gluck]] #[[Luís Vaz de Camões]]
|} ==Later repetitions== Ingres revisited the subject in several later works, including an undated watercolour (Lille, Musée des Beaux-Arts) and paintings such as ''Homer and His Guide'' (1861; Brussels, Royal Collection) and ''The Odyssey'' (Lyon, Musée des Beaux-Arts). In 1854 be began work on a drawing of the composition to be used as a model for the engraver [[Luigi Calamatta|Calamatta]].Condon et al. 1983, p. 112. This drawing, in which Ingres announced his intention to "amplify and complete" his conception, was not completed until 1865, as the artist deliberated at length in choosing the appropriate historical personages to be included. He ultimately added dozens of new figures, including [[Ictinus]], [[Giulio Romano]], [[John Flaxman]], [[Jacques-Louis David]], [[Pliny the Elder]], [[Plutarch]], [[Cosimo de Medici]], [[Louis XIV]], and [[Pope Leo X]]. Ingres also refined his selection by excluding Shakespeare, Tasso, and Camões from the 1865 drawing, as he had come to believe that they were too closely related to the Romantic tendency epitomized by his rival Delacroix. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *Condon, Patricia; Cohn, Marjorie B.; Mongan, Agnes (1983). ''In Pursuit of Perfection: The Art of J.-A.-D. Ingres''. Louisville: The J. B. Speed Art Museum. {{ISBN|0-9612276-0-5}} *Radius, Emilio (1968). ''L'opera completa di Ingres''. Milan: Rizzoli. {{OCLC|58818848}} *Rosenblum, Robert (1990). ''Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres''. New York: H.N. Abrams. {{ISBN|0810934515}}. ==External links== {{commons category|The Apotheosis of Homer by Ingres|The Apotheosis of Homer}} *[http://cartelen.louvre.fr/cartelen/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=22515 Cataloge entry for this work at the Louvre] *[http://cartelen.louvre.fr/cartelen/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=15332 Oil study of Homer's feet for the painting] *[http://cartelen.louvre.fr/cartelen/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=15331 Study of hands for the painting] {{Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Apotheosis of Homer (Ingres)}} [[Category:Paintings of the Louvre by French artists]] [[Category:1827 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Homer]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Aristotle]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Socrates]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Plato]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Alexander the Great]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Dante Alighieri]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Michelangelo]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Raphael]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Molière]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of William Shakespeare]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]]

'''''The Best American Short Stories 1992''''' is a volume in ''[[The Best American Short Stories]]'' series edited by [[Robert Stone (novelist)|Robert Stone]].<ref>Stone, Robert (editor), ''The Best American Short Stories 1992'', New York, 1992.</ref>

{{other uses|Gleaner (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Jean-François Millet - Gleaners - Google Art Project 2.jpg | painting_alignment=right | image_size=350px | title=The Gleaners | other_language_1=French | other_title_1=Des glaneuses | artist=[[Jean-François Millet]] | year=[[1857 in art|1857]] | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=83.8 | width_metric=111.8 | height_imperial=33 | width_imperial=44 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Paris]] | museum=[[Musée d'Orsay]] }} '''''The Gleaners''''' (''Des glaneuses'') is an [[oil painting]] by [[Jean-François Millet]] completed in [[1857 in art|1857]].
It depicts three [[peasant]] women [[gleaning]] a field of stray stalks of [[wheat]] after the harvest. The painting is famous for featuring in a sympathetic way what were then the lowest ranks of rural society; this was received poorly by the French upper classes.
== History == Millet's ''The Gleaners'' was preceded by a vertical painting of the image in 1854 and an etching in 1855. Millet unveiled ''The Gleaners'' at the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon]] in 1857. It immediately drew negative criticism from the middle and upper classes, who viewed the topic with suspicion: one art critic, speaking for other Parisians, perceived in it an alarming intimation of "the scaffolds of [[Reign of Terror|1793]]."<ref name="nyt1">{{Cite news |last=Kimmelman |first=Michael |author-link=Michael Kimmelman |date=August 27, 1999 |title= ART REVIEW; Plucking Warmth From Millet's Light |periodical=The New York Times |publication-place=New York City |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E07E2DC143BF934A1575BC0A96F958260 |accessdate=2008-01-10 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> Having recently come out of the [[French Revolution of 1848]], these prosperous classes saw the painting as glorifying the lower-class worker.<ref name="nyt1" /> To them, it was a reminder that French society was built upon the labor of the working masses, and landowners linked this working class with the growing movement of [[Socialism]].<ref name="Gardner">{{cite book|last=Kleiner|first=Fred|author2=Christian J. Mamiya |edition=12|title=Gardner's Art Through the Ages|publisher=Wadsworth/Thompson Learning|year=2005|location=California|isbn=0-534-64091-5|page=857}}</ref> The depiction of the working class in ''The Gleaners'' made the upper classes feel uneasy about their status. The masses of workers greatly outnumbered the members of the upper class. This disparity in numbers meant that if the lower class was to revolt, the upper class would be overturned. With the French Revolution still fresh on the minds of the upper classes, this painting was not perceived well at all.
Millet's ''The Gleaners'' was also not perceived well due to its large size, 33 inches by 44 inches, or 84 by 112 centimetres. This is huge for a painting depicting labor. Normally this size of a canvas was reserved for religious or mythological style paintings. Millet's work did not depict anything religiously affiliated, nor was there any reference to any mythological beliefs. The painting illustrated a realistic view of poverty and the working class. One critic commented that "his three gleaners have gigantic pretensions, they pose as the [[Moirai|Three Fates]] of Poverty...their ugliness and their grossness unrelieved."<ref name="andrew">{{cite web |url=http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~waste/timeline/story-pic1.html |title=Story behind the picture – The Gleaners |accessdate=2008-01-10 |work=University of St. Andrews}}</ref> While the act of gleaning was not a new topic—representations of [[Book of Ruth|Ruth]] had existed in art—this new work was a statement on [[rural poverty]] and not Biblical piety:<ref name="andrew" /> there is no touch of the Biblical sense of community and compassion in the contrasting embodiments of grinding poverty in the foreground and the rich harvest in the sunlit distance beyond. The implicit irony was unsettling. After the Salon, Millet, short on money, sold his piece for 3,000 [[French franc|francs]]—below his asking price of 4,000<ref name="bullet">{{cite journal |last=Fratello |first=Bradley |date=December 2003 |title=France embraces Millet: the intertwined fates of The Gleaners and The Angelus |journal=The Art Bulletin |volume=85 |issue=4 |pages=685–701|doi=10.2307/3177365 |jstor=3177365 |publisher=The Art Bulletin, Vol. 85, No. 4}}</ref>—after haggling with an Englishman named Binder who would not budge for his meagre counter-offer; Millet tried to keep the miserable price a secret.<ref>Étienne Moreau-Nélaton, ''Millet racconté par lui-même'', (Paris: 1921)</ref> While ''The Gleaners'' garnered little but notoriety during his life, after his death in 1875, public appreciation of his work steadily broadened. In 1889, the painting, then owned by banker Ferdinand Bischoffsheim, sold for 300,000 francs at auction.<ref name="bullet" /> The buyer remained anonymous, but rumours were that the painting was coveted by an American buyer. It was announced less than a week later that Champagne powerhouse [[Pommery|Jeanne-Alexandrine Louise Pommery]] had acquired the piece, which silenced gossip on her supposed financial issues after leaving her grapes on the vines weeks longer than her competitors.
At Madame Pommery's death in 1891, and following the conditions of her will, the painting was donated to the [[Louvre]].<ref name="bullet" /> It now resides in the [[Musée d'Orsay]] in [[Paris]].
== Composition == {{Quote box |quote=What does ''The Gleaners'' show? [The women] embody an animal force deeply absorbed by a painstaking task. The contrast between wealth and poverty, power and helplessness, male and female spheres is forcefully rendered.|source= — Liana Vardi<ref name="vardi">{{cite journal |last=Vardi |first=Liana |date=December 1993 |title=Construing the Harvest: Gleaners, Farmers, and Officials in Early Modern France |journal=The American Historical Review |volume=98 |issue=5 |pages=1424–1447|doi=10.2307/2167061 |jstor=2167061 |publisher=The American Historical Review, Vol. 98, No. 5}}</ref> |width=33% |align=right}}
== Legacy == ''The Gleaners'' is one of Millet's best known works. Its imagery of bending peasant women gleaning was paraphrased frequently in works by younger artists such as [[Camille Pissarro|Pissarro]], [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir|Renoir]], [[Georges Seurat|Seurat]], and [[Vincent van Gogh|van Gogh]].<ref>Pollock, Griselda. ''Millet''. London: Oresko, 1977, p. 48.</ref> Art historian [[Robert Rosenblum]] says Millet's painting introduced "imposing new presences in the repertory of mid-century art, with endless progeny in city and country. [[Honoré Daumier|Daumier]]'s and [[Edgar Degas|Degas]]'s laundresses, and even more so [[Les raboteurs de parquet|Caillebotte's floor-scrapers]], are almost unthinkable without Millet's epic hymn to labor."<ref>*Rosenblum, Robert (1989). ''Paintings in the Musée d'Orsay''. New York: Stewart, Tabori & Chang. p. 90.</ref>
''The Gleaners'' provides evidence of Millet's role as a contemporary social critic. His brutal depiction of three hunched, female paupers segregated from the laborers and the abundant crop in the distance demonstrates his attention to, if not necessarily sympathy for, the plight of the poorest members of the community around Barbizon and its larger neighbor, Chailly, as the area experienced the growing pains of French modernization. Only about thirty-five miles from the French capital (whose population doubled between 1831 and 1851), the rich, broad plain bordering the forest of Fontainebleau was among the earliest with a rail link to Paris, readily lending itself to feeding the burgeoning city. Studies tracing the transformation of rural France in the nineteenth century note that little change in peasant life occurred beyond northern France and the Paris basin until the last quarter of the century. Millet's representation of class strife on a large-scale farm was thus uniquely modern in the 1850s.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fratello|first1=Bradley|title=France Embraces Millet: The Intertwined Fates of 'The Gleaners' and 'The Angelus'|journal=The Art Bulletin |date=2003|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/eds/detail/detail?vid=17&sid=a8ef2419-4c55-4aae-8ef5-fc7aa220e5c3%40sessionmgr4004&hid=4102&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ%3d%3d#bib13|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>
The painting inspired the name of the [[Gleaner Manufacturing Company]].{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} The painting inspired, and is discussed in, the film by Agnes Varda, ''[[The Gleaners and I]]''.

''The Art Bulletin'' 85 (4): 685–701. {{DOI|10.2307/3177365}}. * Kimmelman, Michael (August 27, 1999), "Art Review; Plucking Warmth From Millet's Light", ''The New York Times'', retrieved 2008-01-10 * Kleiner, Fred; Christian J. Mamiya (2005). ''Gardner's Art Through the Ages'' (12 ed.). California: Wadsworth/Thompson Learning. p. 857. {{ISBN|0-534-64091-5}}. * "Story behind the picture – ''The Gleaners''". University of St. Andrews. Retrieved 2008-01-10. * Moreau-Nélaton, Étienne. ''Millet racconté par lui-même''. Paris, 1921 * Pollock, Griselda. ''Millet''. London: Oresko, 1977 * Rosenblum, Robert (1989). ''Paintings in the Musée d'Orsay''. New York: Stewart, Tabori & Chang. {{ISBN|1-55670-099-7}} * Vardi, Liana (December 1993). "Construing the Harvest: Gleaners, Farmers, and Officials in Early Modern France". ''The American Historical Review'' 98 (5): 1424–1447. {{DOI|10.2307/2167061}}.

'''Tony Shafrazi''' born May 8th, 1943, is the owner of the Shafrazi [[Art Gallery]] in New York, who deals artwork by artists such as [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]], [[Keith Haring]], and [[David LaChapelle]].
==Early life and education== Shafrazi was born in [[Abadan, Iran]] to Christian<ref>[http://www.interviewmagazine.com/art/tony-shafrazi/#_ Interview Magazine: "TONY SHAFRAZI" By OWEN WILSON] April 3, 2009</ref> [[Armenian people|Armenian]] parents who divorced when he was two.<ref>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref><ref>Bettina von Hase (February 20, 2010), [http://howtospendit.ft.com/arts-giving/1211-the-fine-art-of-philanthropy The fine art of philanthropy] ''[[Financial Times]]''.</ref> At the age of 13, his father – an oil-company executive – and stepmother took Shafrazi to England and left him to study there.<ref name=people>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref> He first went to a vicarage in [[Bilston]], then to boarding school in [[Whittlebury]]<ref>Bettina von Hase (February 20, 2010), [http://howtospendit.ft.com/arts-giving/1211-the-fine-art-of-philanthropy The fine art of philanthropy] ''[[Financial Times]]''.</ref> and later [[Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College|Hammersmith College of Art & Building]]. He attended the [[Royal College of Art]] from 1963 to 1967<ref>[[Owen Wilson]] (November 2007), [http://www.interviewmagazine.com/art/tony-shafrazi/#_ Tony Shafrazi] ''Interview Magazine''.</ref> before coming to New York in 1969,<ref>Carol Vogel (October 12, 1998), [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/12/arts/another-look-at-bacon-newfound-canvases-shed-more-light-on-a-master.html Another Look at Bacon; Newfound Canvases Shed More Light on a Master] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> where he lectured at several universities, including the [[School of Visual Arts]].<ref>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref>
==Artist== On February 28, 1974, Shafrazi [[Spray painting|spray-painted]] [[Picasso]]'s painting ''[[Guernica (painting)|Guernica]]'', which hung in [[Museum of Modern Art|the Museum of Modern Art]], with the words "KILL LIES ALL" in foot-high letters.<ref>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref> When a guard finally grabbed him, Shafrazi shouted, "Call the curator. I am an artist."<ref>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref> The paint was easily removed as the painting was heavily varnished. It is believed that Shafrazi was protesting the announcement, the day before, of the release on bail of U.S. lieutenant [[William Calley]]. Calley, then under house arrest following his conviction, in 1971, for his part in the [[My Lai Massacre|My Lai massacre]] in Vietnam, had petitioned for [[habeas corpus]]; he had initially been sentenced to life imprisonment. Although his appeal was overturned in June, he was finally released from U.S. Army custody later in the year after having received a limited pardon from [[Richard Nixon]]. Shafrazi was a member of the [[Art Workers' Coalition]], which in 1970 had staged a protest at MoMA by unfurling a copy of the famous [[My Lai]] protest poster ''[[And babies]]'' in front of the ''Guernica'' painting, which itself depicts the tragedies of war and the suffering it inflicts upon innocent civilians. Shafrazi was later given five years' probation, without a trial.<ref>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref>
In regard to his 1974 vandalism of the painting, he gave the following statement to ''[[Art in America]]'' in December 1980: "I wanted to bring the art absolutely up to date, to retrieve it from [[art history]] and give it life. Maybe that's why the ''Guernica'' action remains so difficult to deal with. I tried to trespass beyond that invisible barrier that no one is allowed to cross; I wanted to dwell within the act of the painting's creation, get involved with the making of the work, put my hand within it and by that act encourage the individual viewer to challenge it, deal with it and thus see it in its dynamic raw state as it was being made, not as a piece of history."
==Art dealer== In 1976, only a few years after the spray painting incident, Shafrazi returned to his homeland and became the art advisor to [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|the Shah of Iran]] and [[Kamran Diba]], then director of the [[Teheran Museum of Contemporary Art]].<ref>Carol Vogel (October 12, 1998), [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/12/arts/another-look-at-bacon-newfound-canvases-shed-more-light-on-a-master.html Another Look at Bacon; Newfound Canvases Shed More Light on a Master] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> Shafrazi went to about 15 of the top New York dealers at the time — including [[Leo Castelli]], [[Ileana Sonnabend]], Paula Cooper, John Weber, and Irving Blum — and helped assemble a 20th-century [[Collection (museum)|art collection]] on the Shah's behalf within four years.<ref>Olga of Greece (December 2, 2007), [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/02/style/tmagazine/02masterpiece.html Masterpiece Basement] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> As he did so his power expanded in the art market. The museum Shafrazi had constructed in Tehran to house this collection epitomized the Shah's modern Iranian state, thus the collection was predominantly Western: from [[Impressionism]] to [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract Expressionism]], [[Pop art|Pop]] and [[Conceptual art|Conceptual Art]], including works by [[Andy Warhol]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]], and [[Willem de Kooning]].
In 1978, Shafrazi briefly opened his own commercial gallery in a small Tehran shopfront but closed it because of conditions in the country leading up to the [[Iranian Revolution|1979 Revolution]].
Resettling in New York after the Shah was deposed, Shafrazi converted his rented apartment into a makeshift gallery where he slept on a small loft bed at night.<ref>David Grogan (March 26, 1984), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20087449,00.html Once He Vandalized Picasso's Guernica, but Now Tony Shafrazi Is a Successful Patron of the Arts] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref> In 1979, he opened his first New York gallery, and within a few years he had made his reputation handling talents like [[Donald Baechler]] and then-hot graffiti artists like [[Jean-Michel Basquiat]], [[Keith Haring]], and [[Kenny Scharf]] and also European artists like [[Brian Clarke (artist)|Brian Clarke]], [[Enzo Cucchi]], [[Hervé Di Rosa]] and [[Jean-Charles Blais]].<ref>Carol Vogel (October 12, 1998), [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/12/arts/another-look-at-bacon-newfound-canvases-shed-more-light-on-a-master.html Another Look at Bacon; Newfound Canvases Shed More Light on a Master] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> In 1990, he opened a new 13,000-square-foot gallery at 119 Wooster Street, with an exhibition entitled "American Masters of the 60's" and including [[Carl Andre]], [[Tom Wesselmann]], [[Jasper Johns]], [[Donald Judd]], [[Frank Stella]], and [[Andy Warhol]].<ref>[[Roberta Smith]] (May 11, 1990), [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/11/arts/review-art-so-big-and-so-dressed-up-new-galleries-bloom-in-soho.html So Big and So Dressed Up, New Galleries Bloom in SoHo] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
In 1999, the [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon estate]] chose Shafrazi as its United States representative.<ref>[[Sarah Thornton]] (August 29, 2008), [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/article.asp?id=16013 Francis Bacon claims his place at the top of the market] ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref> In 2004, the gallery opened another space on 26th Street with a large show of paintings by [[Picasso]], [[Francis Bacon]] and [[Jean-Michel Basquiat]].,<ref>[[Roberta Smith]] (November 28, 2004), [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/28/arts/design/28smit.html Chelsea Enters Its High Baroque Period] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
==Personal life== A longtime friend of [[Stephanie Seymour]] and [[Peter Brant]], Shafrazi was [[Groomsman|best man]] at their 1995 wedding in a chapel on an estate outside Paris.<ref>Laura M. Holson (August 20, 2010), [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/22/fashion/22Brant.html Brant vs. Brant: Divorce Celebrity Style] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.tonyshafrazigallery.com Gallery web site]
==References== {{Reflist|3}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shafrazi, Tony}} [[Category:American art dealers]] [[Category:American artists]] [[Category:American people of Armenian descent]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Art crime]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]] archives
revision.text:
[[Image:TractQuakerExtractsShillitoe1820.jpg|thumb|150px|right|[[Quaker]] tract of 1820]] A '''tract''' is a [[literature|literary work]], and in current usage, usually [[religious]] in nature. The notion of what constitutes a tract has changed over time. By the early part of the 21st century, a tract referred to a brief [[pamphlet]] used for religious and political purposes, though far more often the former. Tracts are often either left for someone to find or handed out. However, there have been times in history when the term implied tome-like works. A ''tractate'', a derivative of a tract, is equivalent in Hebrew literature to a ''chapter'' of the Christian Bible.
==History== The distribution of tracts pre-dates the development of the [[printing press]], with the term being applied by scholars to religious and political works at least as early as the 13th century. They were used to disseminate the teachings of [[John Wycliffe]] in the 14th century. As a political tool, they proliferated throughout Europe during the 17th century. They have been printed as persuasive religious material since the invention of [[Johannes Gutenberg|Gutenberg]]'s [[printing press]], being widely utilized by [[Martin Luther]] during the start of the [[Lutheran]] movement of [[Christianity]].
[[Image:CIM Gospel Tract.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A [[Good News (Christianity)|Gospel]] tract printed by the [[China Inland Mission]]]]
===Religious tracts=== As religious literature, tracts were used throughout the turbulence of the [[Protestant Reformation]] and the various upheavals of the 17th century. They came to such prominence again in the [[Oxford Movement]] for reform within the [[Church of England]] that the movement became known as "Tractarianism", after the publication in the 1830s and 1840s of a series of religious [[essay]]s collectively called ''[[Tracts for the Times]]''.
These tracts were written by a group of [[Anglican]] [[clergy]] including [[John Henry Newman]], [[John Keble]], [[Henry Edward Manning]], and [[Edward Pusey]]. They were [[theology|theological]] discourses that sought to establish the continuity between the Church of England and the [[Church father|patristic]] period of [[History of Christianity|church history]]. They had a vast influence on [[Anglo-Catholicism]]. They were learned works and varied in length from four to over 400 pages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/mod/tracts-list.html|title=Modern History Sourcebook: The Tracts for the Times, 1833-1841|work=fordham.edu}}</ref> An important center for the spreading of tracts was the London-based [[Religious Tract Society]].<ref>[http://www.ne.se/jsp/search/article.jsp?i_sect_id=330356&i_history=1 The article ''traktatsällskap''] in ''[[Nationalencyklopedin]]'', web edition, visited 2006-11-22 (Swedish)</ref> Tracts were used both within England, affecting the conversion of pioneer missionary to China, [[Hudson Taylor]], as well as in the crosscultural missions that movements such as Taylor founded: the [[China Inland Mission]].
[[Charles Spurgeon]] wrote many tracts, and in addition to these evangelical writings, his "Penny Sermons" were printed weekly and distributed widely by the millions and used in a similar way, and they still are today. In America, the American Tract Society distributed vast quantities of tracts in multitudes of languages to newly arriving immigrants at [[Ellis Island]] and sought to assist them in their struggles in their new country.<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/02/24/101855405.pdf The New York Times, ''The Gospel in 30 Tongues''], February 24, 1907</ref>
[[File:Wipermail.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Tracts are often left in places with high amounts of public traffic. This tract was left under a vehicle [[windshield wiper]].]]
The publishing of tracts for religious purposes has continued unabated, with many evangelical tract ministries{{Who|date=October 2011}}, in particular, existing today.<ref>http://www.tractlist.com</ref> In the United States, the [[American Tract Society]] has continuously published literature of this type since 1825. {{anchor|JW|Watch Tower}} By the late 19th century, [[Bible Student movement#Watch Tower Society|Bible Students]] associated with ''[[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Zion's Watch Tower Tract Society]]'' were distributing tens of millions of tracts each year;<ref>"Kingdom Proclaimers Active in All the Earth", ''The Watchtower'', May 1, 1994, page 15, "In 1881, just two years after the Watch Tower was first published,... In a few years, tens of millions of tracts were being distributed annually in many languages."</ref> by the start of World War I, they had distributed hundreds of millions of tracts in dozens of languages worldwide.<ref>"Witnesses to the Most Distant Part of the Earth", ''Jehovah's Witnesses - Proclaimers of God's Kingdom'', ©1993 Watch Tower, page 421, "Before the devastation of the first world war was unleashed, an extensive witness had been given worldwide.... Millions of books, as well as hundreds of millions of tracts and other pieces of literature in 35 languages, had been distributed by the Bible Students."</ref> The Watch Tower Society continues to publish hundreds of millions of religious tracts in more than 400 languages, which are distributed by [[Jehovah's Witnesses]].<ref>"Presenting the Good News—With Tracts and Handbills", ''Our Kingdom Ministry'', January 1991, page 8, ©Watch Tower</ref><ref>"“The Silver Is Mine, and the Gold Is Mine”", ''The Watchtower'', November 1, 2007, page 18, "Tracts, brochures, magazines, and books have been translated into 437 languages."</ref>{{unreliable source?|reason=The sources listed have a reputation for academic dishonesty. Third party sources should be cited here.| date=March 2016}}
As evangelistic tools, tracts became prominent in the [[Jesus movement]]. One of the most widely distributed was "[[The Four Spiritual Laws]]" authored by [[Bill Bright]] of [[Campus Crusade for Christ]] and first published in 1965. "This Was Your Life" was the first of many tracts written by [[Jack Chick]]. Later [[Chick tract]]s followed the pattern of vivid [[cartoon]] images and began to focus on issues of [[Fundamentalist Christianity]], including vehement [[Anti-Catholic]] opinions.
In the 1980s and 1990s, [[Last Days Ministries]] reprinted articles in the ''Last Days Newsletter'' by [[Keith Green]] and other contemporary and historic writers including [[David Wilkerson]], [[Leonard Ravenhill]], [[Winkie Pratney]], [[Charles Finney]], [[John Wesley]], and [[William Booth]]. More recently [[Living Waters Publications]] prints tracts such as "The Atheist Test" or "Are You Good Enough to Go to Heaven?", as well as tracts which feature attention-getting illusions or gags. These include the "[[The Great News Network#Million Dollar Bill Tract Seizure|Million Dollar Bill]]", which caused a legal controversy in June 2006. Most Christian tract ministries operate as non-profit "faith" organizations, some to the degree that they do not require a fee for their tracts. One of the most productive among these is Fellowship Tract League, which has printed over 4 billion Gospel tracts since 1978, available in over 70 different languages, and have been distributed into more than 200 countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fellowshiptractleague.org/about.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201004133/http://www.fellowshiptractleague.org/about.htm |archivedate=2008-12-01 |df= }}</ref>
"Tracting" is a colloquialism commonly used by [[Missionary (LDS Church)|Mormon missionaries]] to refer to door-to-door proselytizing, whether or not actual tracts are dispensed.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}}
===Political tracts=== {{main|Pamphlet}} Brochure-like tracts, also known as [[pamphlet]]s, advocating political positions have also been used throughout history as well. They were used throughout Europe in the 17th century. In the 18th century, they featured prominently in the political unrest leading up to the [[American Revolution]], and in the English response to the [[French Revolution]], a "pamphlet war" known as the [[Revolution Controversy]]. A well-known example of a far-reaching tract from this era is [[Common Sense (pamphlet)|''Common Sense'']] by [[Thomas Paine]].
Tracts were used for political purposes throughout the 20th century. They were used to spread Nazi propaganda in [[central Europe]] during the 1930s and 1940s. According to Jack Chick, his impetus to design cartoon-based religious tracts was brought on by hearing of a similar promotional tool used by Communists in [[China]] to wide success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/information/authors/chick.asp|title=Biography of Jack Chick|work=chick.com}}</ref> In the months before the [[John F. Kennedy assassination]], [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] handed out pamphlets promoting [[Fidel Castro]] and [[Communism|Communist]] [[Cuba]] on the streets of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]].
==See also== [[Image:TractPhiladelphiaQuakerPage12Shillitoe1820.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Page from a tract by Thomas Shillitoe]] {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Chick tract]] * [[Marprelate Controversy]] * [[Minor tractate]] * [[Miss Clack]] * [[Nezikin]] * [[Pamphlet]] * [[Tractate]] * [[Tractatus (disambiguation)|Tractatus]] }}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tract (Literature)}} [[Category:Books by type]] [[Category:Documents]] [[Category:Activism by type]] [[Category:Religious literature]] [[Category:Ephemera]]

page.title: United States Department of Veterans Affairs emblems for headstones and markers

revision.text:
[[File:Seal of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.svg|The U.S. Veterans Affairs seal.|thumb]] The [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] (VA) maintains many cemeteries specifically devoted to veterans. Most have various rules regarding what must take place in order to be interred there. ==Procedure== The VA only permits graphics on Government-furnished headstones or markers that are approved emblems of belief, the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] [[Union Army|Union Shield]] (including those who served in the U.S. military through the [[Spanish–American War]]), the [[Confederate States of America|Civil War Confederate]] [[Southern Cross of Honor]], and the [[Medal of Honor]] insignia. [[Arlington National Cemetery]] has similar restrictions on headstones, though it is maintained by [[US Department of the Army]]. The [[religious symbol]]s are rendered as simple [[Monumental inscription|inscriptions]] without sculptural [[relief]] or coloring other than [[black]]. The emblem of belief is an optional feature.{{cite web |url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/Funerals/Scheduling-a-Funeral/Headstones-and-Niche-Covers/Government-Headstone-Niche-Covers |title=Arlington National Cemetery > Funerals > Scheduling a Funeral > Headstones and Niche Covers > Government Headstone/Niche Covers |quote=White marble niche covers (15¾ x 11¼ x ¼) generally contain 11 lines of text with or without an optional emblem of belief.}} Generally the VA adds a new symbol a few months after receiving a petition from a faith group. However, the [[Wicca]]n symbol was only added in 2007 to settle a lawsuit filed on behalf of several families by [[Americans United for the Separation of Church and State]] in November 2006.{{cite news|last=Banerjee|first=Neela|title=Use of Wiccan Symbol on Veterans’ Headstones Is Approved|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/24/washington/24wiccan.html?_r=0|accessdate=August 1, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 24, 2007}} The VA added emblem of belief #37 – "WICCA (Pentacle)".{{cite press release|url=https://www.au.org/media/press-releases/veterans-affairs-department-must-accommodate-wiccan-symbol-on-memorial-markers|title=Veterans Affairs Department Must Accommodate Wiccan Symbol On Memorial Markers At Government Cemeteries, Says Americans United|publisher=AU|date=June 8, 2006|accessdate=July 11, 2007}}{{cite web|title=Stewart v. Nicholson|url=https://www.au.org/our-work/legal/lawsuits/stewart-v-nicholson|publisher=AU|accessdate=August 5, 2013}} A separate parallel lawsuit was filed on behalf of two Wiccan churches and three families by the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] in September 2006, which was resolved by the same settlement.{{cite press release|title=Veterans Denied Right to Post Religious Symbol on Headstones, ACLU Charges|url=https://www.aclu.org/religion-belief/veterans-denied-right-post-religious-symbol-headstones-aclu-charges|date=September 29, 2006|publisher=ACLU|accessdate=5 August 2013}}{{cite news|last=Goodstein|first=Laurie|title=Pagans Sue on Emblem for Graves|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/30/washington/30grave.html|accessdate=August 1, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 30, 2006}}{{cite press release|title=Veterans Win Right to Post Religious Symbol on Headstones|url=https://www.aclu.org/religion-belief/veterans-win-right-post-religious-symbol-headstones|date=April 23, 2007|publisher=ACLU|accessdate=5 August 2013}} The first interfaith headstone, which includes a Wiccan [[pentacle]] for Jan Deanna O'Rourke and a [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian Cross]] for her husband, was installed at Arlington National Cemetery on May 1, 2007, and dedicated on July 4, 2007.{{cite journal|last=Blackwell|first=Christopher|title=A First Dedication at Arlington|journal=Action|year=2007|url=http://aren.org/newsletter/2007-lammas/action.php?num=2|accessdate=August 5, 2013}} File:Cypress hills 22.jpg|[[Spanish–American War]] veteran in [[Cypress Hills National Cemetery]] File:Cypress hills 23.jpg|Medal of Honor recipient [[Anton Olsen (U.S. Navy)|Anton Olsen]] in [[Cypress Hills National Cemetery]] File:fort logan national cemetery 4.jpg|Gravesites at [[Fort Logan National Cemetery]] during Memorial Day 2006 ==Headstone and marker symbols== The following emblems and emblem numbers are publicized as available for Government headstones and markers as of September 2017.{{cite web|author=National Cemetery Administration |url=http://www.cem.va.gov/hmm/emblems.asp |title=Available Emblems of Belief for Placement on Government Headstones and Markers – National Cemetery Administration |publisher=Cem.va.gov |date=2013-07-03 |accessdate=2013-08-24}} A process is in place to consider approving additional religious or belief system emblems requested by the families of individuals eligible for these headstones and markers. Each emblem is given its official USVA name and designation, with added additional links for related symbolism (*) and for related movements (†). revision.comment: Added {{[[:Template:merge from|merge from]]}} tag to article ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{merge from|Netherlands Carillon School|discuss=Talk:Utrecht School of the Arts#Proposed merge with Netherlands Carillon School|date=July 2018}} {{Unreferenced|date=September 2011}} [[Image:Kmt hilversum.jpg|thumb|right|Entrance of the department in Hilversum]]
The '''HKU University of the Arts Utrecht''' ({{lang-nl|[[Hogeschool]] voor de Kunsten Utrecht, HKU}}) is a [[performing arts]] and [[visual arts]] educational institution in [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]], [[Netherlands]].
== Overview == The institution has 680 teachers and staff members. The HKU cooperates with the [[Utrecht University]] at many levels, and in 1987 consolidated the Utrecht Conservatory, Carillon School and the Dutch Institute for Church Music into the HKU music department.
The HKU University of the Arts Utrecht offers preparatory courses, bachelor's and master's programmes and research degrees in fine art, design, music, theatre, media, games and interaction and arts management.
With more than 3,900 students, the HKU is one of the largest art and culture-oriented institutes in Europe.
The HKU University of the Arts Utrecht is internationally oriented and involved in numerous international programmes and projects. The HKU maintains contact with almost 200 educational institutions abroad for the purpose of exchanging lecturers, students and projects. Almost 20% of the students come from outside the Netherlands. Foreign students can attend the HKU as a regular student, an exchange student in programmes such as Socrates/Erasmus, a bilateral exchange programme or as an MA, MPhil or Ph.D student. Since 1999 the HKU is an accredited institution of the Open University.
== Bachelor's programmes == The '''HKU University of the Arts Utrecht''' offers bachelor courses and pathways in fine art, design, music, theatre, media, games and interaction, arts education and arts management.
Courses in English: *Bachelor of Fine Arts (partially) *Bachelor of Music
Courses in Dutch: *Bachelor of Arts and Economics *Bachelor of Creative Media and Game Technologies *Bachelor of Design *Bachelor of Education *Bachelor of Theatre
Courses in English for Exchange students: *The HKU offers courses for international students, who wish to study 1 or 2 semesters abroad.
== Master programmes == At the Utrecht School of the Arts, you can choose from a variety of master's courses and pathways in English: *Master of Fine Arts in Scenography *Master of Arts in Fine Art *Master of Music, Performance *Master of Music, Music Design
Courses in Dutch: *Master of Education in Arts *Master Interior Architecture *Master Crossover Creativity
== Other higher education institutions in Utrecht == * [[University of Professional Education Utrecht]] (HU — Hogeschool Utrecht) * [[Utrecht University]] (Universiteit Utrecht) * [[University College Utrecht]] affiliated with [[Utrecht University]]
== Notable alumni ==
* [[Najib Amhali]] * [[Pascal van Assendelft]] * [[Barry Atsma]] * [[Lois van Baarle]] * [[Henze Boekhout]] * [[Erik-Jan de Boer]] * [[Floortje Dessing]] * [[Saskia Diesing]] * [[Jetske van den Elsen]] * [[Martijn Fischer]] * [[Wouter Hamel]] * [[Rob Hornstra]] * [[Janine Jansen]] * [[Emmy Verhey]] * [[Lies Visschedijk]] * [[Herman Witkam]] * [[Barbara Woof]]
== See also == * [[Higher Professional Education]] * [[Utrecht Network]]
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061010080346/http://english.hku.nl/ Utrecht School of the Arts] (HKU — Hogeschool voor de Kunsten Utrecht) — page in English.

revision.text:
Radio and club DJ [[Gilles Peterson]] every three months or so does an ''All Winners Special'' in which he replays the previous few months' best new [[track (song)|tracks]]—both [[single (music)|singles]]/individual [[album]] tracks as well as whole albums—he has either played out when [[DJing]] or played on his [[BBC Radio 1]] show ''[[Gilles Peterson#Radio 1|Worldwide]]''. At the end of the year, these winners, plus a few further favourites that may have been overlooked, get compiled into a [[longlist]]. Listeners of the show then get to vote this longlist down to a shortlist of ten '''''Worldwide Winners''''' in each section, via the Radio 1 website, which Gilles then plays over the last couple of editions of his [[radioshow]] at the end of the year. It has been compiled in various forms at the end of every year since 1998 to present, though the first few years did not involve any public vote.
In recent years, from 2004 onwards, this has been expanded into the '''''Worldwide Winners Awards''''' with an event held at a London club venue during the very end of December or beginning of January, with outside broadcast recording by [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]], edited highlights of which are broadcast on a further one or two editions of the radio show at the start of January. Also further sections were added, like "Best Clubnight", "Best Recordshop", "Best Compilation Album", and a special award called "The [[John Peel]] ''<nowiki>'Play More Jazz'</nowiki>'' Award" (a tribute to his Radio 1 colleague who died suddenly in 2004) given to an artist, often a newcomer, who has displayed special noteworthy work over the year.
__TOC__
